Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Liquid-drop impacts on granular surfaces and the universality in granular impact cratering
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Granular impact cratering by liquid drops is likely familiar to all of us who have watched raindrops splashing in a backyard or on a beach. Such a ubiquitous phenomenon is directly relevant to many important natural, agricultural and industrial processes such as soil erosion, drip irrigation, dispersion of micro-organisms in soil, and spray-coating of particles and powders. It is even more surprising that granular impact cratering by liquid drops and asteroid impact cratering on planetary bodies show quantitatively similar features in terms of the energy scaling and the shape of impact craters. The present project investigates the fast dynamics of impinging liquid drops and impacted granular particles during impact events, which are then used to develop a quantitative model for describing the morphology of raindrop imprints in granular media. The project also aims to reveal universal features of granular impact cratering and search the link between different granular cratering processes including solid-sphere impact cratering, liquid-drop impact cratering, asteroid impact cratering and explosion cratering. To probe the fast impact dynamics, students working on the project are trained in the state-of-the-art high-speed and radiological imaging techniques. The project can provide practical guides to various activities in environmental protection and industry involving liquid-drop impacts on granular surfaces.

Technical Abstract
Directly related to two long-standing problems in soft matter research, i.e., drop impact on solid/liquid surfaces and granular impact cratering by solid spheres, liquid drop impact on granular surfaces is notoriously complicated. The objective of the project is to investigate the dynamics of liquid-drop impact on granular surfaces and explore universal features of granular impact cratering across widely different energy scales. Combining high-speed photography with advanced radiological imaging techniques, the study aims to uncover the detailed dynamics of liquid-drop impact in granular media and provide a quantitative model for predicting of the outcome of liquid-drop impact events. The experimental techniques and physical insights developed in the research are considerably useful for solving difficult problems faced in the study of drop impact dynamics and granular impact cratering in much broader contexts. Moreover, the study helps to illustrate universal features in granular impact cratering and may open up a new way to probe high-energy granular impact cratering associated with asteroid strikes. The study can also potentially benefit soil science research on soil erosion, astrophysical research on asteroid strikes and geological research on primordial rain activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a raindrop impacts on a sandy surface, the surface readily deforms with sand grains pushed and ejected away from the impact point by the impinging drop, which leaves an impact crater as the vestige of the fast impact event (see Image). This granular cratering process by liquid drops is relevant to a large number of natural and industrial phenomena, ranging from soil erosion, to the dispersion and spreading of airborne pathogens, and to the spray coating of powder materials. Our research aimed to decipher this elegant and ephemeral process using state-of-the-art experimental techniques. The study provided a fundamental understanding of this complex multiphase fluid process, involving the dynamics of liquid drops, impact-induced granular flows and the morphology of impact craters. 

Our first set of experiments characterized the morphology of granular craters by liquid drops. In particular, we showed that the diameter of granular craters follows a power-law scaling with the impact energy of liquid drops, similar to that of asteroid impact craters. Inspired by theories from planetary science, we have developed a quantitative model to interpret different morphologies of drop-impact granular craters. Moreover, we have also studied granular cratering by liquid drops on wet granular media as an extension of our study on impact cratering on dry granular media. In addition, to identify the universal feature of granular cratering processes, we have conducted a series of experiments examining the dynamics and morphology of granular craters induced by explosion. The results allowed us to compare the similarities and differences of various different impact cratering processes.     

Our second set of experiments was directed to understand the dynamics of impacting drops. In particular, we investigated the impact force applied by liquid drops on impacted surfaces. A temporal scaling of the impact force was measured in our experiments, which confirmed previous theoretical and numerical predictions. More importantly, we studied the effect of viscosity on the peak impact force experimentally and developed an asymptotic theory explaining our experimental finding. We have also extended our study from the impact force to the stress distributions underlying impacting drops, which addressed a broad issue of the erosion ability of liquid drops on solid surfaces. The dynamic variables of drop impact probed in our study provided a microscopic explanation on the origin of drop-impact granular craters.     

Our work has led to 7 publications in top journals including one article in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America, one invited article in Physics of Fluids and one back scatter photo in Physics Today. In addition, the PI has also been invited to write a review in the Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics on the subject, which is targeted for publication in early 2021. The videos of drop impact on granular media from our study won the Gallery of Fluid Motion award from the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Fluid Dynamics (DFD). The videos uploaded by APS on Youtube, "Raindrop Impact on a Sandy Surface", has attracted more than 930,000 views to date. My group has also given total 20 talks at seminars and conferences on the project. The grant financially supported one graduate student and one Hispanic postdoctoral researcher. Moreover, we have recruited 10 undergraduate students at the University of Minnesota for the project, which included four female students. In addition, my lab has also held two Hispanic REU students from Brazil and Chile in conducting research on the subject. Beyond the academic work, the PI has participated the outreach program every summer in the Minnesota State Fair for six years in a row.
